review_blob: I had this when it first came out and wasnt as impressed, ie, I didnt order another. But I have been able to find it more readily and have ordered it several times, and it has changed. It has identified itself as an American (USA!) Wheat, to indicate I think that is not that crappy faux-belgian stuff tasing of bubble gum. It tastes of beer, but with the twist you expect from wheat. It is drinkable and I actually order more than one... or two.

Recently I did a 2 week gluten free experiment. That meant drinking things I normally wouldnt. Cider, vodka tonics, and 3 gluten free beers. This is by far the best. Not at all like what I would be drinking with gluten in it, but acceptable as an alternative. Appley, but so much better than the cider I tried. Ciders seem too sour, and this is more beery than sour. Dont care about the aroma or appearance, because when what you are looking for is the experience, you drink it oput of the bottle, bypassing your nose and eyes!

I can remember having this on cask at the GBBF and it knocked my socks off. Now I drink alot of it in the bottle, its my brother-in-laws favorite. Its always good. I wish it werent so strong, it affects the drinkability and my head the next day.
Their use of hops is spot on, the aroma and taste full and exciting.

I feel like I must have gotten a different beer from everybody else. My sister and brother in law love this beer and told me and other sis to go to Poes on Sullivans Island (cool place!) and drink the Coast IPA. What showed up in our glasses was a big disappointment, it was thick and murky, like Inishuk IPA, couldnt see anything through it. Please people, learn the art of brewing! My sister had a couple sips and pronounced she couldnt drink it so I had hers, not cause I wanted it but I didnt want to waste the money! The taste and aroma had elements of a good beer but it was completely let down by the appearance and lack of drinkability. I would not order another one. We could have had a bad keg but the other reviewers noted its cloudiness, may be it doesnt bother other people.

This has been a favorite choice the past 2 years on my trips to New Hampshire, but sadly this year, the pleasure has gone. Wanted to make sure it wasnt the fault of the pub, so went across the street to Sweet Tomatoes and found the same thing. My b-in-law is a big fan of this beer and he was also very disappointed to the point that we switched to a different beer. Not sure what happened, bad batch? Dont put it on the market if its bad, your customers should be sure of what they are getting. The great taste and aroma we recall was gone from this sample. Also the appearance was much worse, murky and unappetizing.

Only got this because the pale ale was bad and the ipa hasnt been on for months. Amber? It was really dark and I would have guessed it was a brown ale only I have had their brown ale and this isnt it. It was flat, and the taste was predominantly licorice. It only cost a dollar because it rained that day. Overpriced.

Yall are harsh. There is a place for this type of beer. Its weak and watery but refreshing and bubbly and perfect for when you want to drink alot but not get drunk. It needs to be drunk from the bottle and obviously needs to be very cold. But sometimes there is a situation where bud light is the appropriate beer for the occasion.

I have had a 6-pack in the fridge for a month, I can only get through it slowly. I havent actually finished a bottle, but my brother has. The appearance is a concern. It is so thick it is almost sludge. You cannot see through it at all, just shadows. I drink other unfiltered beers and you can still see through them. If you drink with your eyes you wont like this. The aroma is of banana bread and room deodorizer. The mouthfeel as expected is thick. There is an immediate pleasant hop flavor that fades to medicinal. The bitterness lasts long on the tongue. The alcohol is very apparent. I think the carbonation level is pretty pleasant, at least they got that right!

I made three visits to the tavern this month and each time have had the pale ale and it has been right on the money. True to style, with a very similar feel to what you can get in british pubs, albeit not cask. But the mouthfeel and carbonation is right, contrary to most US ales. In the past I have been disappointed with their ales but something has definitely improved here. I know they are brewing these cause I can smell it sometimes!

Started going back to park tavern this month and have been pleasantly surprised to find the beer remarkably improved! This was a good solid IPA, the right amount of maltiness and strong on hops. Not overcarbonated so it slipped down the throat beautifully. This is what I expect but find it hard to get from a brewpub. Good job guys!

So last week I had the Avery dryhopped ale and rated it very low, this week they had Loose Cannon at the same bar and it was incredibly similar to the Avery. Except better. The tase was not as similar to fruit juice, and I actually had another. Well, my friend didnt want his so I drank it. Too cloudy, that is unnecessary. And too hoppy, also unnecessary. I love hops but I also love beer. Make it taste like beer.

I know this is a really low rating but the glass I got at Taco Mac, which is supposed to be a reliable beer bar, was really this bad. The aroma and taste can be summed up in two words: pressed ham. The color was a cloudy green. Talk about mother ship, this is the space alien of beer.

I think it would have been a decent mild had they not messed with it. Reading the review prior to mine (the only other one at this time) I see he found it to be tainted too, although he was guessing fouled lines and taste of strawberry. I got a taste of mint and cardomom. Its not sour like fouled lines, so its the purposeful addition of some spice that ruined the beer.

This was on tap and I am guessing it was somehow tainted in the processing because it cant be the same beer the other raters are discussing! The defining taste is of disinfectant or medicine. Chemical. Could not finish it. Had a dales on the table at the same time and that was tasting great, so I know it wasnt a problem with my taste buds! I cannot tell you more about the flavor because that was really all I could taste, it was so strong.

I drink this in the can version and think its super, but this rating is for the draught version. Had it after trying an overhopped beer so was concerned that my tongue wouldnt be able to taste it. Compared it with 2 other pale ales on the table. This one really stood out, tasting exactly like a pale ale should, malt and hops balanced, very high drinkability that left you wanting more. My only complaint really is that the alcohol is too high, this is something you can drink alot of and that could lead to trouble!

I hope I am rating this properly, as I noted the rules dont allow a separate listing for the cask version of an existing beer. So this was a cask version that was apparently dry hopped with Apollo hops. The waiter was very excited about the aroma and said that the entire cold room smelled great when they tapped it. So this is very hoppy. And the aroma was lovely, of citrus and grapefruit. But the appearance was very off-putting, very cloudy. The taste initially was pleasing of very strong citrus fruits, but the underlying beeriness was missing and the aftertaste not "more-ish". In a blind tasting I am not even sure you would have identified this as a beer, maybe more like a grapefruit soda.  The bitterness left an unpleasant feeling in the mouth. I understand that this is for hopheads only, but by not using more restraint and better hopping techniques you are ruining what might be a good beer. I have had plenty of dry hopped beers and they dont need to end up so thick and cloudy.

The predominant taste here is honey. Even the smell is honey. This is too sweet and not hoppy enough. Do you know what I mean when I say its not "beery"? Other than that, it was clear, tawny, and did have some identifiable grapefruit flavor. Bottle.

At least I assume I have the right IPA. It was on cask at the brewery, and the beertender told me it was the normal IPA with minor additions when it is casked. I am rating it high because it is the best cask ale I have had in the US. I miss the heck out of real ale and this guy is really trying to get it right, and coming very close.
This is a quality IPA that some of the bigger boys would be proud to produce. This was fresh at the brewery and maybe the better for it. The hoppiness brought back fond memories of England.
Maybe I was all caught up in the moment of being in Asheville, but I really enjoyed this on draft at the Bier Garden.
I hate to say it because I did enjoy their pale ale, but this was such a bad beer, I couldnt drink it. I was at the Thirsty Monk in Asheville.

Is this what I was drinking? I was in Taco Mac, it is their beer of the month... March 17th, Virginia Highlands. All it says is Guinness, not extra or draught. But it was on tap. It was like drinking lager only it was black. As a lager I would have rated it higher, maybe average. But this is supposed to be stout. It most definitely is NOT a stout. Blah!
Atlanta Cask Beer Festival. I thought it was terrible, my friends thought it was funny. It won first place.

Cask Beer Festival Atlanta. Watery. A friend told me to try it, that it was great. But right next to it was Blackstones Mesa Stout that did it right. I cant find that to review here but it was a really good coffee beer with the right body.
On tap at the Cask Beer Festival Atlanta. This was the best of the bunch. (21 casks) Closest thing to cask ale, anyway. 5% ABV says you dont have to brew to a high gravity to produce a good beer!

Bottle at Ecco restaurant, Atlanta. Had just read an article about organic beer that included this one so was delighted to find it here. Unfortunately it tasted of butterscotch. Really, do they have no quality control? It wasnt as spoiled as some of the samples reviewed here but it was definitely not the flavor the brewer intended. Its diacetyl and as strong as I have had in a beer recently. Yuck.

On draft only. I stopped buying the bottled version when they moved the bottling to their new brewery, they are doing something terribly wrong. Hope they fix(ed) it! Meanwhile the draft is just as good as ever, delicious and hoppy, everything you could ask for in a pale ale, and I guess that rye must help out with the dryness, or something. I doubt you can actually taste it. Its the Amarillo that does it for me!
On cask at the brewpub. This is the worst beer I have ever had in this country. It was undrinkable. I was waiting for someone so had to sit in front of it for 30 minutes, but could not drink it!
